text: Is R any good apart from the ecosystem? I wanted to prototype a quick idea I had for a friend using R but looking at <https://learnxinyminutes.com/docs/r/> made me give up just looking at the code

elements.text: Is R any good apart from the ecosystem? I wanted to prototype a quick idea I had for a friend using R but looking at
made me give up just looking at the code

text: R is a competent wrapper for C and Fortran, as a programming language it's widely remarked that it was clearly designed by statisticians. I preferred R to Python as I think R has more 'personality' if that makes sense

elements.text: R is a competent wrapper for C and Fortran, as a programming language it's widely remarked that it was clearly designed by statisticians. I preferred R to Python as I think R has more 'personality' if that makes sense

text: otherwise I probably can't add anything which hasn't been covered here: <https://www.burns-stat.com/pages/Tutor/R_inferno.pdf>

elements.text: otherwise I probably can't add anything which hasn't been covered here:

text: Python is also a competent wrapper for C and Fortran in many situations, right? Like anything that uses NumPy for instance.

elements.text: Python is also a competent wrapper for C and Fortran in many situations, right? Like anything that uses NumPy for instance.

text: both Python and R were motivated specifically for inter-operating with C

elements.text: both Python and R were motivated specifically for inter-operating with C

text: I did some R learning last year, and I really liked some parts like ggplot2. I’ve tried the Python port of that earlier, and it was a far cry of it.

elements.text: I did some R learning last year, and I really liked some parts like ggplot2. I’ve tried the Python port of that earlier, and it was a far cry of it.

text: the R ecosystem is truly its killer feature

elements.text: the R ecosystem is truly its killer feature

text: Shiny is crazy good, Rcpp and related packages just work :tm:

elements.text: Shiny is crazy good, Rcpp and related packages just work

text: I’ve been learning Julia lately. The speed of the compiled code is great. It has its own problems, sure.

elements.text: I’ve been learning Julia lately. The speed of the compiled code is great. It has its own problems, sure.

text: nothing like the issues with R

elements.text: nothing like the issues with R

text: R is in a position where most broken elements can only be documented not fixed, and performance is a fever-dream

elements.text: R is in a position where most broken elements can only be documented not fixed, and performance is a fever-dream

text: It’s very hard to fix things that are deployed to production by many others.

elements.text: It’s very hard to fix things that are deployed to production by many others.

text: that's part of it and you are accumulating technical debt along the way where at each design choice there are multiple options and everything doesn't automatically interoperate, then you look back at something done a long time ago a realize it's no longer exactly the right choice

text: I tried using PyPy for one example task, and it just failed. Something or other was not supported.
